required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Sex or no Sex: That is the Question.
clinical_study.official_title: Sex or no Sex: That is the Question. Impact of Coital Sexual Intercourse on the Clinical Pregnancy Rate After Embryo Transfer.

brief_summary.textblock:
This study aims to evaluate the impact of sexual intercourse and orgasm in the 72 hrs following embryo transfer of blastocysts on the clinical pregnancy rate.
An impact on sexual activity and a decrease in the frequency of intercourse has been observed in infertile couples. In couples who undergo assisted reproductive technology (ART), sexual relations have an additional component that can condition them, such as the fear of influencing the outcome of the cycle.
The usual practice in ART cycles has evolved towards a preference for blastocyst-stage embryo transfer, both in fresh in vitro fertilization (IVF) cycles and in frozen embryo transfer (FET) cycles.
The investigators consider it important to elucidate whether coital intercourse after embryo transfer (ET) has an impact on the clinical pregnancy rate after the transfer of blastocyst-stage embryos.

detailed_description.textblock: It is proposed to carry out an observational, prospective study, in which women with a heterosexual sexual relationship are included, who carry out an embryo transfer, in a FET cycle in the Dexeus Woman Reproduction Medicine Service and who agree to participate in the same.

primary_outcome.description: Clinical pregnancy rate measured by ultrasound with the presence of a positive fetal heartbeat

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Until 13 weeks after embryo transfer procedure
secondary_outcome.description: The loss of a pregnancy during the first 13 weeks of pregnancy
Number of live birth after embryo transfer

arm_group.description: women with a heterosexual sexual relationship after embryo transfer
women without a heterosexual sexual relationship after embryo transfer

study_pop.textblock: -After detailed oral and written information on the nature of the study, patients who meet the inclusion criteria will give their written consent. According to this consent, patients agree to have their data used and analyzed for the present study.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Women with a heterosexual sexual relationship
- That they carry out an embryo transfer, in a FET cycle
Exclusion Criteria:
- Exclusion criteria are not foreseen
